question: To investigate people's ability to divide their attention between two different tasks, college students were asked to listen to a passage of expository prose and at the same time to inspect a set of photographs, unrelated to the passage, that were projected one by one at a rapid rate. At the end of the dual-task presentation, the students were tested both for their memory of the passage and their memory of the photographs. To establish a baseline for this dual-task condition, the same students also were tested for their memory when each of the component tasks was presented alone. The following graph shows the results. <image 1> In a study of the effectiveness of divided attention, it is most important that the experimental design include
options: ['a counterbalance of the order in which participants are tested in the baseline and dual-task conditions', 'a consistent order in which participants are tested in the baseline and dual-task conditions', 'an equal number of men and women as participants', 'verification that participants believe themselves capable of dividing attention']
description:
The image is a bar graph illustrating the results of a study comparing memory performance under dual-task and single-task (baseline) conditions. The x-axis represents the "Type of Memory," with two categories: "Prose" and "Photograph." The y-axis indicates the "Percent Correct," ranging from 0 to 75%.

There are four bars in total:

1. For "Prose":
   - A white bar labeled "Dual-task condition" reaches approximately 25%.
   - A striped bar labeled "Baseline (single-task) condition" also reaches approximately 25%.

2. For "Photograph":
   - A white bar labeled "Dual-task condition" reaches approximately 60%.
   - A striped bar labeled "Baseline (single-task) condition" reaches approximately 75%.

The legend at the bottom clarifies that:
- White bars represent the "Dual-task condition."
- Striped bars represent the "Baseline (single-task) condition."

The graph demonstrates that memory performance for both prose and photographs is lower in the dual-task condition compared to the baseline condition. However, the difference is more pronounced for photographs than for prose. This suggests that dividing attention has a greater impact on visual memory (photographs) than on auditory memory (prose). 

The question asks about the importance of certain factors in the experimental design of a study investigating divided attention. Based on the graph, the focus is on ensuring that the comparison between dual-task and baseline conditions is fair and unbiased. Therefore, the most critical aspect would be related to the order in which participants are tested in these conditions.
